parts.text: Hello my name is then and I'm going to have a
conversation with Ellen. Several former principal lives in
Oral History Project at the New York Public Library. It is Thursday
afternoon May the fourteenth two thousand and fifteen. And this has
been recorded at the end to high school. Braille in talking book library
in New York City.
Ellen thank you for coming and we look forward to hearing your story where
wherever you would like to thank you for giving me this way
to express myself on my start with
hearing loss.
Actually starts when I was eight years old I grew up in Brooklyn New York
. And my first hearing test was in school when I was in
third grade and I learned that I had a slight hearing loss on
my left ear. My parents took me to an E.M.T. Tucker in
Manhattan. I believe it was the first time I was ever on the subway and
I learned that at that time in one thousand nine hundred fifty they did not
have. The. Hearing aids that could help me. I believe they did have very
large aids that people with very severe hearing loss
used but there was nothing appropriate for me I did have what is called a
sensory neural hearing loss which I believe is the most common one and
it's not at least in this day. Curable.
Nowadays we have all kinds of accommodations.
So I learned after that to sit up front in school
. But I didn't really find at that time that I had any major
problems with my theory. I functioned well.
However. Well a little bit later when I started dating it was a little bit of a problem
because it was my left ear and when I go out with these young fellows who had cars
my left ear would be facing them and they would be looking straight ahead not me
driving. So that made it a little difficult to hear some subset. Other
than that I was not having major problems. Every now and then at work
. Once I got to the work world I did but even in school
. Even in high school and college overall I
don't recall having any major problems however the real problem
Began. When I was in my forties. And I was
already. In the work world and working in a law firm
. Where. Attorneys are not the easiest people to work
for they're always on deadline. And stressed out. So the
last thing they want to do is work with somebody who has hearing loss.
And I had just changed jobs working in a law firm.
Any new kind of law that I had not experienced before so I did not know the
vocabulary attorneys would come talk to me and then they would walk
away but continue talking. And I couldn't see them I knew they were talking
I hear the sounds but I could not determine what the words were
. That was to say the least very stressful. That's when I
finally went to have a hearing test I had discussed it with my friend who was at the
time the head of the hearing at St Vincent's Hospital
and she arranged for me to see the audiologist there and the audiologist said
Oh yes you are having massive hearing loss. So I'm doing this test.
So they couldn't hit me with hearing aids would do anything specific. Right then and
there they wanted to wait a while and a while later I did go back. I had
another test I was first sent to an E.M.T. doctor and
then for a CAT scan because one of the things that is done
is to make sure that the hearing loss is not from the tumor. So they checked that
out before they send you to an audiologist. I.
Eventually did get to an audiologist and get hearing aids which for the
first time were very very made me feel very very stressed
because I wasn't comfortable wearing them. I was hearing a lot of
sounds I hadn't heard in a long time. I heard background noises that were not
wonderful I had recently and that was the state of the art in
I guess this was the late one nine hundred eighty S.. And.
I really didn't love them. However things have changed.
I now have what are called digital hearing aids in those days they were called
animal and these are much better much more
sophisticated think blocking up more sounds that they don't need to hear but seem to
know I don't know how what I do and why. So it's
really an amazing thing and they just are my best friends
because without them I am not to function.
So that's basically what that hearing loss was about and I started. Having a lot of
problems in the work world because when I first got these analog aids
they did not help me the way the ones I have now help me and therefore
I couldn't always tell what people were saying to me at work. I couldn't tell what they were saying
to me on the telephone. I couldn't deal with attorneys coming to me and
talking to me from behind me I didn't even know they were there some of the time
and I had a lot of trouble. All of a sudden in my forties. Keeping jobs
. And I was crying all the time and
. Just not doing well. My family didn't really understand all
this because they just didn't understand hearing loss and no one in my family has hearing loss.
Some of my friends were truly wonderful because some of them had
experiences with people and their families who have hearing loss or they learned right
away to look at me when they speak and tell me clearly what they wanted to
say if they didn't get it they knew how to rephrase. To get my attention they
would tell me and so they they really. Well the people who
kept me going and eventually through someone at work
. I learned of an organization called the Hearing Loss Association
. And it took me about. A month or two months to actually
go there after I called up and got all the literature because I just
didn't feel comfortable going. But going there was an incredible
experience for me because as I said at this meeting I realize that all
these other people. Have the same problem I did. They all
understood what I was going through because they all had severe hearing loss
and that was in the year two thousand and I have since become really good
friends with some of these people. And I. Have learned an incredible amount of
things and have gotten involved in advocacy myself so that
first meeting was. Eye opening or ear opening
I started to learn different technology that I should have what's
called a cheap coil in my hearing aid and if I hit the button that goes to Tikal
. In the room where we have the hearing loss meetings then was what is called an
induction loop or hearing loop. And the sound would come
wirelessly from wires around the ceiling.
Into my ear and it would block out. Other Unwanted
sound so I could only hear what was being spoken into a microphone. And
that was an incredible thing to learn. And suddenly the sounds were really crisp and
clear and I had to sit in the room and forget that I even have here a lot
so that was the beginning. But I was still having difficulties at work I was beginning
to learn some things about how you can get something on your
telephone. Or your certain kind of amplifier that will help
but I really didn't know enough to keep myself. On the job. I kept losing
jobs because things would happen that I would make a mistake not hear something
correctly and some of it was really very painful because some of these
companies who didn't want to fire me because of hearing loss and
that's against the law. But just try to make my life miserable and try to
get me to quit and that was extremely painful
. Finally I did get a job working in the
home of. A prominent family and I
mostly work by email even though my boss was in the next room. So that
really helped a lot I think. Email has been an incredible
invention for everyone but particularly for people with hearing loss I did not have to
deal with not hearing something and I am rather articulate and write
well and certainly comprehend the written word so I had no
problems there. I did work for a number of years and that was really
very very much. However during all of that time I started getting more and more
involved in the Hearing Loss Association. It started when I was
at one of my first meetings and somebody invited me to join a group to
dinner. At this restaurant the group was talking about getting an
errand. From the restaurant. To. Put
in their newsletter and they were discussing the amount of money they should
ask and this is going to be a whole new project but they were going to ask right then and there in
that restaurant and now it's the end of the meal and six people who are just
got up and walked out and I was there and I said are we going to try
to get in it from this place. So I just went over to the manager and
explained we eat in this restaurant every month when we have our meetings and
. I think it would be great if you guys could take out in it. Well that
was the beginning of my career as an advertising manager for the hearing loss
. So I did that for a little while and that was very gratifying in.
You know brought in some money into the endless Association and then in two thousand and
six actually I guess it was two thousand and five when we started preparing for it
. One of my colleagues in the Hearing Loss Association
. Decided that it would be a good idea to have what I call walks for
hearing you know what. And. In two thousand and
six we did our first one up in Westchester with the Westchester
chapter and the Hudson Valley chapter
and that was a big learning experience but since I'm very into networking
and organizing this was definitely the right place for me
. So that in two thousand and eight when it was decided we would have our first one here in New York
City I was named chair of the work
and I worked day and I think trying to get different
organizations to join us and split the money that we mayn't
get friends and family to form teams and
then I also work with the park to make sure that all the details of the
actual site of where we were going to walk was all in order.
And that was. An incredible experience. I was.
It's.
Practically comatose near the end but I. Was not I had something
else. Certainly some volunteers but not.
All that many and it was very successful.
We did raise one hundred twenty five thousand dollars which was terrific for her first
walk and we had over five hundred walkers and that was amazing standing
there in the park and seeing these people and thanking them. Mostly I got to know all these
people through e-mail. This was the first time for many of them that I had ever
seen them in person so it really made me see the value of the computer
and how you can really maximize anything through e-mail
. That was before social media but in any case e-mail.
And then I did work on the what we're hearing in subsequent
years but I was no longer the chair because it just became too much and other
people who had an interest to follow my lead and I acted as
their counselor and gave information as needed. But I'm
still even now in two thousand and fifteen involved in some aspects
of the work every year I write a letter to my friends and family. I do this on the
computer and I ask if they would like to work with me or make a
donation and I have raised you know on my own for five thousand
dollars for my friends and family in different years.
And that's been very very gratifying.
Most recently I wrote an article and it was just
published in the hearing loss magazine which is senior national magazine
for the Hearing Loss Association and the article was about the
accessibility.
At the new nine eleven. Memorial and Museum
downtown in Manhattan. I had been involved in two thousand and
eleven with the designer. And getting
a new scene. Looped.
We two of us had actually written to and met with people
from the nine eleven Museum which was not yet built but they were
. Working.
I'm design. And we brought in
Experts and we are hearing loop or as it's also
called induction loop design. And now
that the museum opened last May We wanted to see the results
of our advocacy and so two of us went down and met with
the head of external affairs and the
person who was in charge of accessibility and we were
given this wonderful tour from exhibit hall to the exhibit hall and
every single place there is an exhibit has a hearing little one
every single place where there is audio there is captioning
. So it was really just a very nice experience to
see that the work that you do you know really benefits he says
I did in the interim starting in two thousand and ten becoming the head of the New York
City loop Committee which is part of the hearing loss associations work
and after we got some wonderful publicity we
actually had twenty two people.
On this committee. And. Each of us took on a different
sector. Kind of.
Then use their art of necessity from cultural institutions.
And museums and. Movie theaters in
lecture halls. So we have been working to get as many opinions as we
can. Loop so that people like me just have to walk into the venue
hit a button on my hearing aids and it blocks out all of the noise and I will
only hear what's coming through the microphone that is attached to
an actual wire that's like a telephone wire. That is installed
either. Near the ceiling around the periphery of a room or
near the floor around the periphery of a room and sometimes in a
complicated place like a theater a big theater. It's all around all the
seats and that goes around more than once different configurations to make the sound
equal. Where any wherever and one who sits and if you don't have a T.
coil or even if you don't have hearing aids you can use a special headphone
to access this wonderful sound and also block out the
sound you don't want to hear. So as of now there are hearing loops
in for. Theater big Broadway theaters.
Richard Rogers the longtime chain of George Gershwin
and very recently the involvement of Lincoln Center at these
very very exciting thing in sight. I feel really good
that I have been instrumental in in making some of these things
happen so that's really really my story
and at this point I no longer think about my hearing aids or my
hearing loss I should say I just put my hearing aids in first thing in the morning
and I function you know all day and night. I don't. Any
longer feel sorry for myself I'm not feeling sad about it I'm just
feeling that. This happened and maybe it happened so that I could have the
opportunity to do the very things I'm doing to to help others and. That
does feel very good that sounds terrific. That's basically my story.
Oh that's that's really really interesting. Excellent to do
all this work. Words of wisdom would you like to share
with do you want people to know. Don't talk to somebody who
has a hearing loss or what do you see for the future.
OK Well in terms of what others need to know to deal with people with hearing
loss. One is to look if you know the person has hearing loss
look at the person because as soon as you turn away the sound doesn't
travel the same way and people who have hearing loss often depend upon lip reading
or. Body. Reading really. So that if you're not looking at
the person it makes it much harder if you want to talk to someone who has hearing loss and is
maybe looking the other way the first thing to do is tap them on the shoulder lightly
rather than speak to them because they may not respond. At all so it's good to
have the light shining. I'm the person
who's speaking so that they can the person with hearing loss can can
see that person. It's also good for people who do
not. Have a hearing loss but are speaking to others who do to make sure they don't put their
hands in front of them out. And of course it makes it more difficult when someone has a
beard or a mustache but you know those are the basic things. And
if someone doesn't really understand what you're saying and you kind of realize that it's always
good to try to rephrase it because some sounds are easier to hear than others so that if you
rephrase it you may have a better chance of the person hearing you and of course none of those
work. It's always good to have pencil and paper to write it down in this day and
age with smartphones. You can just use text or some program on
your smartphone that allows the other person to see what you've typed
And that's that's also a very good thing but what I'd really
like to see happen in the future is that more people who have
hearing loss step up to the plate get involved in advocacy it will
help you in the individual too. Get
past whatever your woes are about your hearing loss. And
. Begin to make you feel that you were really doing something very
purposeful helping other people. It's truly an amazing
feeling and for the most part people want to do the right thing. If
you engage someone about advocacy. Most of the
time. Unless they just can't do it financially then you
will try to put in that little Or they'll try to get other kinds of equipment
and maybe after I recall oh this they'll be a new technology but whatever it
is I think it's important for those of us with hearing loss to get
out there and try to make that happen and to nicely
complain when things don't work so that people know I mean if
you just go home and complain to a friend that doesn't help anyone and
if you just say to a venue that gee you know that technology is not
clear or this isn't working or it didn't work at all I think that's important because you're
not only helping yourself you're helping all the other people who are down the
line. We'll use that technology. So that's my hope for the future
Great thank you so much this is really interesting Allan thank you for coming.
You're very welcome.
